‘in an instant, in a very short time, surprisingly quickly’
comment:
In some languages, this compound is currently no longer perceived
as being semantically irregular; its figurative meaning can be determined at
best due to the etymology. For this reason, some of the terms mentioned below
are not considered as idioms and do not appear in idiom dictionaries. I address
this problem pragmatically, by translating the compounds as literally as possible.
For example, for the German in einem Augenblick—actually translating
as ‘in an instant’—I chose the “etymolo gical” translation “in an eye-glance”;
in this way, the similarities of the imagery (‘rapid movement of the eyelids’)
are apparent. Piirainen 2016, p. 507

comment: leave out "weep" since crocodile tear in itself are idiomatic and in some languages the notion of "weep " is not included. The distribution of frequencies was similar

idiom_string: in black and white / (with) black on white
description_english: ‘1. reduced to writing; written down or in print, and therefore official; written proof of something; 2. written down or in print, and therefore very clear, in a comprehensive manner’
comment: probably also contains simple "black and white" as colour examples

description_english: ‘to understand or deduce the real meaning of something; to perceive a hidden message or additional information, even though it is not stated explicitly’

idiom_string: one can count sth. on (the fingers of )one hand)
description_english: ‘it is a very small number, there are surprisingly few of certain things’
comment: Changed, by allow allowing for "on one hand"

description_english: ‘to waste time and effort in creating something that already exists orredoing work when it has already been done satisfactorily; to rethink an already working system, method, etc. that has long been accepted and even taken for granted’

idiom_string: to give sb. the green light
description_english: ‘to encourage or allow someone to proceed, to give someone permission to do something that they were planning to do or have asked to do’

idiom_string: to be on the same wavelength as someone
description_english: ‘to have similar ideas, interests, and opinions (to another person’s); to understand each other very well’

idiom_string: the devil is / lies in the detail
description_english: ‘something looks easy to do but to carry it out proves much more difficultdue to small details that are overlooked and can cause serious problems’

‘a paradoxical constellation that looks as if fate would be involved, a disastrous surprise without clear human intervention (said whensomething is surprisingly different than planned, when the opposite of what one had hoped for occurs)’
‘a day full of failures or disasters, when something very sad or unpleasant happens’
‘to the utmost, until the very end’
‘to put oneself in a difficult situation by doing something wrong or making foolish mistakes, to bring about one’s own ruin or downfall and seriously harm oneself’
‘someone (a dead person) would be very angry or upset about something which is happening now, if they were still alive to experience it’

idiom_string: the other side of the coin
description_english: ‘a completely different and perhaps contradictory aspect or attitude of a subject or situation; one of two differing views, showing the disadvantages of something that is actually advantageous’
‘under all circumstances, at any rate, regardless of the costs and other disadvantages’
comment: merged two columns

description_english: ‘to be a lucrative and inexhaustible source of income, to constantly generate a lot of money; to be a treasure trove, i.e. a source of rich information’
comment: make "real" optional

description_english: ‘to be a lucrative and inexhaustible source of income, to constantly generate a lot of money; to be a treasure trove, i.e. a source of rich information’
comment: make "vrai" optional

idiom_string: to put all (one’s)eggs in / into one basket
description_english: ‘to stake everything on one chance, to invest all one’s money, effort, trust, etc. in one thing, without dispersing one’s risks, so that if it is not successful, one has no other chance’

idiom_string: to lose/miss the thread (of something) / to lose one’s thread
description_english: ‘to get confused or forget what one wants to say, especially if it is long and complicated, to lose the train of thought’

idiom_string: to talk to a wall / brick wall
description_english: to unsuccessfully try to persuade or reason with someone’
‘to be confronted by two equally threatening dangers, pressed from two sides simultaneously; to have a dilemma, to be involved in a conflict without the possibility of choosing one of two sides’
comment: leave out "caught". Otherwise low freqency

idiom_string: to keep one’s head above water
description_english: ‘to stay out of trouble, especially out of financial difficulties, to keep away from insolvency; to efficiently fight for survival, to avoid being overwhelmed by one’s tasks or commitments’
comment: left out "stay afloat" because it does not exist in French or Ger,an

idiom_string: like a bolt from /out of the blue/out of a clear blue sky
description_english: ‘completely surprising, without warning or preparation, totally unexpectedly (especially of negative events, shattering news, etc.)’
comment: https://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/like+a+bolt+out+of+the+blue

description_english: ‘a peaceful and quiet period before a period of trouble or activity’

idiom_string: to shoot up/spring up/pop up like mushrooms
description_english: to grow rapidly; to suddenly come into existence in great numbers’
comment: added "pop up" https://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/like+mushrooms

idiom_string: to die/to be dropping like flies / to go down like flie
description_english: ‘to rapidly collapse, die, or drop out in great numbers within a short period of time, usually for the same reason (referring to a group rather than an individual)’
‘to spend one’s time aimlessly, with useless, unimportant activities while one is waiting for time to pass, in order to escape boredom’
‘(used as exclamation to express urgency): let us seize on the opportunity now; it must be done now or not at all’
‘someone will not stay alive for very long, is approaching the end of his/her life or existence; someone will not survive or remain in a particular position for much longer’

idiom_string: sb.’s last hour has come / sb.’s last hour has struck
description_english: ‘someone’s death is very close; someone must die’
comment: more fixed in english therefore do not use context function. A, b version?

description_english: ‘to become completely independent and self-reliant; to follow one’s inclinations, especially differing from what others are doing’
comment: only use "left" because "go" is a frequent verb and would produce too mayn FPs to the right. "Go" to the right of this idiom would also be very rare. Also do not use sentence conctext because  English "in one's own way" also has the meaning of "in a manner that is unique to oneself."

idiom_string: to shut / slam the door in the/sb.’s face/to shut / slam the door in front of someone’s nose
description_english: ‘to reject someone harshly, to refuse to talk to someone and terminate any further negotiations’

idiom_string: to take off one’s hat to sb.
description_english: ‘to have great respect for someone and express one’s admiration for their ability or achievement’
‘to be ready and willing to set about hard work; to prepare oneself for a difficult task

idiom_string: to point the finger / an accusatory finger at sb
description_english: ‘to blame someone for a mistake or blunder they have made; to identify someone as the guilty person, to denounce them in public for their behavior’
comment: make "at optional because it is also optional in French

idiom_string: to turn one’s back on sb./sth.
description_english: ‘to turn away from someone, something; to refuse to help someone; to stop being involved in something; to forsake or abandon someone, something’

idiom_string: to welcome/greet sb. with open arms
description_english: ‘to accept, greet with great willingness; to show that one is very happy to see or meet someone or to have them as part of their group etc.’

idiom_string: to poke/thrust/stick one’s nose into sth./everything
description_english: ‘to meddle curiously in other persons’ affairs; to take an inquisitive interest in things that do not concern oneself and become absorbed in it’
comment: added "stick" also very common. Merriam-Webster. (n.d.). Stick/poke one's nose in/into. In Merriam-Webster.com dictionary. Retrieved June 19, 2021, from https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/stick%2Fpoke%20one%27s%20nose%20in%2Finto

description_english: ‘to make economies, live frugally and use fewer resources when food or money is scarce; to start in earnest on an activity; to make financialsacrifices or cut back on spending´

idiom_string: in the blink of an eye / in the twinkling of an eye
description_english: ‘in an instant, in a very short time, surprisingly quickly’

idiom_string: to stand with both feet on the ground; to have one’s feet / both feet on the ground
description_english: ‘to have a sensible and practical attitude to life; to be able to cope with life, to be free from fanciful, impractical ideas’
comment: probably also literal occurences, only left context because verbs are frequent.

description_english: ‘to intentionally increase someone’s pain or shame; to make a difficult situation even worse for someone; to add deliberately to someone’s misery’
‘something felt to be pleasant, healing and soothing, if one is in an emotional depth’
‘this is so good or excellent that it defies belief, there is no way it could be true; it exceeds all expectations but probably cannot be realized’
‘to have a good and generous character; to be a friendly, helpful, forgiving person whose qualities are much appreciated’
comment: changed from verb idiom to noun idiom

description_english: ‘to lose one’s power of reasoning, to become so excited or confused that one gets into a panic and behaves irrationally’
comment: Relatively fixed idiom. Leave whole cosntruction, otherwise too many FPs.

description_english: ‘to annoy or disturb someone constantly; to exasperate someone by the repetition of some irritating action; to be a nuisance’
‘to protect oneself from danger or difficulties, without worrying about other people; to escape from a disagreeable predicament’

idiom_string: sb’s hands are tied/ to be tied/bound hand and foot
description_english: ‘to be unable to act because of some restrictions or hindrances; to have obligations which severely restrict one’s actions and freedom’
comment: only use (a) because (b) "to be tied / bound hand and foot" does not exist in French and German

description_english: ‘(to see something) without using any artificial help, without an optical ninstrument such as binoculars, microscope or telescope’
